subject: US History

metadata.title: POST 07 09

config.question: What is the significance of the Judiciary Act of 1789?

choices.content: It established a federal court system.
It allowed the courts to punish acts of sedition.
It conferred on the president the right to nominate the chief justice.
It stated that “When the President of the United States is tried, the Chief Justice shall preside.”

answer_3.response: Congress provided for a federal court system. The Judiciary Act of 1789 created a Supreme Court staffed by a chief justice and five associate justices. It also set up thirteen district courts authorized to review the decisions of the state courts.

answer_2.response: Congress provided for a federal court system. The Judiciary Act of 1789 created a Supreme Court staffed by a chief justice and five associate justices. It also set up thirteen district courts authorized to review the decisions of the state courts.
